cluster_relations.rel_desc: Misinformation can cause serious real-world consequences.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media: Impacts and Social Change
remarks: The consequences are phrased for rumors, conspiracy theories, and propaganda, but these are typically forms/effects of misinformation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Rumors spreading on social media can cause serious real-world consequences.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media: Impacts and Social Change

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Conspiracy theories can lead to serious real-world consequences.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media: Impacts and Social Change

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Propaganda disseminated via social media can cause serious real-world consequences.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media: Impacts and Social Change

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject content can bring about or lead to the specified real-world consequences or impacts.
args.justification: All four relations describe a causal link where a type of online information (misinformation, rumors, conspiracy theories, propaganda) can bring about serious real-world consequences. The semantics are identical (content → consequences), only the specific content type varies, so they should share a single canonical predicate.
args.remark: The modal qualifier "can" is modeled via qualifiers; the canonical predicate is kept as the neutral causal verb "causes".

args.justification: Each relation connects a form of online information or content to its offline consequences. Grouping them under an "information_consequence_relation" class captures this family of content → impact links while remaining broader than the specific predicate "causes".
The rel_hint_type is "causal" and the descriptions all describe that the subject leads to or brings about the object (real-world consequences), which is a prototypical causal relation.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject content can bring about or lead to the specified real-world consequences or impacts.
executed_decisions.justification: All four relations describe a causal link where a type of online information (misinformation, rumors, conspiracy theories, propaganda) can bring about serious real-world consequences. The semantics are identical (content → consequences), only the specific content type varies, so they should share a single canonical predicate.
executed_decisions.remark: The modal qualifier "can" is modeled via qualifiers; the canonical predicate is kept as the neutral causal verb "causes".

executed_decisions.justification: Each relation connects a form of online information or content to its offline consequences. Grouping them under an "information_consequence_relation" class captures this family of content → impact links while remaining broader than the specific predicate "causes".
The rel_hint_type is "causal" and the descriptions all describe that the subject leads to or brings about the object (real-world consequences), which is a prototypical causal relation.
